questions.stem: After a minor, no‑injury fender‑bender, what is the first thing you must do?

options.text: Leave to call your insurer from home.
Stop, check for injuries, and secure the scene.
Argue about who is at fault.
Refuse to move your car under any circumstance.

questions.explanation: You must stop, check for injuries, and make the scene safe. Leaving is hit‑and‑run with severe penalties.  [oai_citation:45‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: If no one appears injured and it’s safe, where should you position vehicles after a collision?

options.text: Leave them in traffic to preserve evidence.
Move them out of traffic to a safe location.
Block the lane so others must slow down.
Drive away separately without exchanging info.

questions.explanation: Move vehicles out of traffic when safe to prevent secondary crashes, then call 911.  [oai_citation:46‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: Which documents must you show after a collision when asked?

options.text: Only your phone number.
Driver’s license, registration, insurance, and current address.
Social Security card and birth certificate.
Only the insurance card.

questions.explanation: The handbook lists those four items specifically.  [oai_citation:47‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: Which statement about hit‑and‑run is true?

options.text: It’s okay to leave if the damage seems minor.
Failing to stop is hit‑and‑run and the punishment is severe.
You may leave if you call your insurer first.
It applies only on freeways.

questions.explanation: You must stop at any collision. The handbook warns that penalties for hit‑and‑run are severe.  [oai_citation:48‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: You scrape a parked car and cannot locate the owner. What must you do?

options.text: Leave without doing anything.
Leave a note with your name, phone, and address and report the collision to law enforcement.
Move the car to a better spot and leave.
Call your insurer only.

questions.explanation: Leave your contact info securely and report the collision.  [oai_citation:49‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: When must a collision be reported to law enforcement according to the current handbook rules?

options.text: Only if a police officer witnesses it.
When anyone is injured or killed, following the timeline in the current handbook.
Only when you believe you are at fault.
Never — insurers handle all reports.

questions.explanation: The handbook requires a report to law enforcement when there are injuries or death, within the stated timeframe.  [oai_citation:50‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: When do you file a DMV collision report (SR‑1)?

options.text: Only if you caused the collision.
Only when law enforcement tells you to.
When the current handbook rules require it (for example, injury/death or property damage above the DMV threshold) within the stated timeframe.
Never — the police file it.

questions.explanation: Each driver must file the SR‑1 with DMV when the handbook conditions apply; law enforcement will not file it for you.  [oai_citation:51‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: Which is true about proof of financial responsibility?

options.text: You only need it when buying a car.
You must have proof when you drive and must show it after a collision.
Minors never need insurance.
It is optional if you drive carefully.

questions.explanation: Proof of insurance is required when you drive and must be shown after a collision.  [oai_citation:52‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: You are in a collision without proper insurance. What may happen?

options.text: Nothing if you were not at fault.
Your driving privilege may be suspended under current rules, and you may need an SR‑22/SR‑1P to reinstate.
Police will automatically file your DMV paperwork for you.
Only your insurance rates can change.

questions.explanation: The handbook notes suspension is possible regardless of fault and explains SR‑22/SR‑1P reinstatement requirements.  [oai_citation:53‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: Who assumes financial responsibility when a driver is under 18?

options.text: No one — minors are exempt.
The car dealer.
Parents or guardians.
Only the school.

questions.explanation: Parents/guardians take on financial responsibility for drivers under 18.  [oai_citation:54‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: You hit a dog that ran into the road. What should you do?

options.text: Leave; animals are not covered by law.
Try to lift the animal into your back seat.
Call the nearest humane society or law enforcement and do not move the injured animal.
Post on social media and drive away.

questions.explanation: Contact authorities/humane society; do not try to move an injured animal.  [oai_citation:55‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: At a serious injury crash you witness, what is the best immediate action?

options.text: Call 911 and follow dispatcher instructions.
Move injured people yourself right away.
Block the roadway with your car.
Argue with bystanders about fault.

questions.explanation: Call 911 immediately when anyone is hurt and follow instructions.  [oai_citation:56‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: You buy a used car in California. What must you do regarding ownership?

options.text: Keep the old owner’s registration for a year.
Transfer title/ownership and complete DMV steps within the current handbook’s timeframes.
Drive with a bill of sale only, indefinitely.
Wait until your first smog check to transfer title.

questions.explanation: Ownership transfer must be completed within DMV timeframes listed in the current handbook.  [oai_citation:57‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: Which statement about California registration is correct?

options.text: DMV will register any vehicle, regardless of emissions.
Vehicles used in CA must be registered here and meet CA emission control requirements.
Out‑of‑state cars never need CA registration.
Only new cars must meet CA emission rules.

questions.explanation: All vehicles registered in CA must meet CA requirements, including emission controls; DMV cannot register vehicles that do not qualify.  [oai_citation:58‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: A tow truck arrives uninvited and pressures you to use a specific body shop. Best response?

options.text: Sign any papers to speed things up.
Politely decline and choose a licensed shop you trust; get written estimates first.
Hand over your title for a discount.
Let them take the car; you can decide later.

questions.explanation: You choose the repair facility. Avoid high‑pressure tactics and never sign blank/incomplete documents.

questions.stem: Smart step before authorizing repairs is to:

options.text: Request a written estimate and clarify parts/warranty.
Permit any repair without limits.
Sign a blank authorization to save time.
Let the shop choose whether to inform your insurer.

questions.explanation: Get written estimates and clarify parts and warranty. This prevents misunderstandings and fraud.

questions.stem: Which items are most helpful to document at the scene?

options.text: Photos of damage/positions, date/time/location, and witness contacts.
Only your own opinion of fault.
A selfie to post online.
None; documentation is unnecessary.

questions.explanation: Accurate documentation supports fair claims handling.

questions.stem: For a minor with a provisional license, which is true?

options.text: Collisions/violations have no licensing consequences.
DMV may restrict, place on probation, or suspend driving after collisions/violations under current rules.
Parents are never involved.
Insurance proof is not required for minors.

questions.explanation: The handbook describes actions against a minor’s license after collisions/violations and notes financial responsibility for minors.

questions.stem: What should you do with an injured animal after a crash?

options.text: Attempt to lift and carry it.
Tie it to a post until help arrives.
Do not move it; call humane society or law enforcement.
Ignore it and leave.

questions.explanation: Do not move injured animals; contact authorities.  [oai_citation:59‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: Proof of insurance must be presented:

options.text: Only during vehicle purchase.
When you drive (including drive tests) and after collisions when requested.
Only on freeways.
Only if the other driver asks nicely.

questions.explanation: Carrying and showing proof of financial responsibility is required.  [oai_citation:60‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: You strike a fence beside the road and no one is around. What is required?

options.text: Leave immediately; it’s private property.
Try to find the owner; if not possible, leave a note with your contact info and report the collision to law enforcement.
Call your insurer only.
Remove the damaged section to hide the evidence.

questions.explanation: Follow the same procedure as striking a parked vehicle or property: leave contact info and report.  [oai_citation:61‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: Which contact detail is specifically listed by the handbook for notes left after damaging a parked vehicle?

options.text: Your social media handle.
Your name, phone number, and address.
Only your first name.
A PO box is enough with no name.

questions.explanation: Leave your name, phone number, and address securely attached to the vehicle/property.  [oai_citation:62‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: In a minor two‑car collision with no injuries, the safest immediate step is to:

options.text: Stay in the travel lane to ‘mark the spot.’
Move both cars to a safe location if possible and then exchange information.
Block multiple lanes so others slow down.
Leave to avoid delaying traffic.

questions.explanation: Moving out of traffic when safe helps prevent further crashes.  [oai_citation:63‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)

questions.stem: Who can file the injury/death collision report to law enforcement?

options.text: Only the drivers involved.
Only the police officer who arrives.
You, your insurance agent/broker, or your legal representative, according to current rules.
No one — it’s optional.

questions.explanation: The handbook allows your insurance agent, broker, or legal representative to file the report when injuries/death occur, within the required timeframe.  [oai_citation:64‡DriverHandbook_CA_EN.pdf](file-service://file-JZ5buQ9fdTyc75quRFSXq5)
